reviews.review_msg: Natalie is such a caring and great prof! Her classes aren't heavy on exams and she puts a focus on projects/participation instead! Definitely recommend her class if you get the chance to take it!
The kindest prof I have ever had!

Natalie is one of the best profs I have had a SFU. She is kind, willing to help and engage in discussions to help your group with the projects, and her lectures are never boring. She tries to give examples from her experience that are relevant to the weeks material. The course content is 100% useful for a career in HR. I am taking her other class.

Anyone who gives Natalie less than 5/5 is lying. She is hands down one of the best professors I have ever had. She is a fair marker and provides a ton of feedback on assignments and presentations. She is always accessible to answer questions and genuinely wants her students to succeed. Do yourself a favour and take this course with her.

One of the upper division HR courses where participation is like 30% of your grade. Read the chapter/case and come to class prepared. Sounds boring, but, Natalie makes this course engaging and fun. She cares about her students and gives great feedback even if you weren't asking for it. Overall a really nice prof and would definitely recommend her.
She treats her class like its her family. So heartwarming.

Natalie has a passion for HR and teaching. You can tell she is genuinely proud of her students accomplishments and spends time making sure you are successful in the course. Workload was fair and creative. Would definitely take a lther course with her again.

Natalie is such an amazing prof, she made me fall in love with HR. She cares about her students and their success. The best way to do well in her class is to do the readings in advance and PARTICIPATE lots. Participation is whats gonna separate a B+ student from an A student.
Natalie is an amazing professor who is genuinely interested and passionate about HR. She is extremely organized, gives good feedback, and brings snacks to class at the end of the semester!

Natalie is one of my favourite profs at SFU. You can tell that she genuinely cares about her students and the topics she teaches. She is quick to answer emails and is a fair marker. She creates a safe space for students to share their opinions. However, the course is a lot of work so you need to be serious about it!

Natalie is a super nice and patient professor! You can tell she is super invested into the course material and genuinely enjoys the material she teaches. Class is participation heavy but she makes the class super enjoyable and makes it inclusive. Follow rubrics, go to office hours, participate, and hope you get a good group!

Natalie is the sweetest, and so knowledgable in Recruitment & Selection. Participation is 30% ,so make sure you read the cases and/or chapter before coming to class. You need to put effort into the assignments and group projects, but she's a pretty lenient marker. Just make sure you follow the rubric.

Nathalie is absolutely amazing! I have never had a professor so kind and willing to help like Nathalie. She is super organized with the lectures and super sweet and understanding. If you participate lots, complete all your assignments, you will be absolutely fine in her class. I've never had a professor bringing us snacks at the end of the semester

I learned lots of useful bits and pieces for Recruitment and Selection. The class is mostly taught by the students, but she adds her feedback in at the right times. Her lectures are kind of boring. The cases are pretty easy to read. I would take a class with her again.

Excellent professor; very helpful, but she won't give you answers. You have to figure it out yourself. Her accent could be hard to understand sometimes, but after the first two lectures, it is ok. Course materials are very relevant to those of you who are planning to do recruitment in the future. Assignments were well related as well.

This class is the easiest class I have ever taken. We did two papers and a presentation, no exams! She sat back and let us teach all of the lectures, so there wasn't much of her teaching. As long as you read the case and particiapte you will do well. Using outside research for your papers will help as well. She is helpful when you ask for help.
